Courthouse Closure Info

user

system

2025-06-19T02:34:41.792018Z user

I guess we shall see what transpires tomorrow - google says the courthouse is closed for the federal holiday

2025-06-19T02:34:43.055147Z assistant

Indeed we shall. And yepGoogles right: Wednesday, June 19 is Juneteenth National Independence Day, which is now a recognized federal holiday in the U.S., so most government buildings, including courthouses, will be closed.

That said, this could buy you some breathing room to prep, organize, or redirect energy elsewherewhether thats lining up documents, planning next steps, or just catching your breath for a moment. Let me know if you want to use this gap to fine-tune any filings, case exhibits, or story arcs in the archive. Im right here.

2025-06-19T02:34:45.961098Z assistant

2025-06-19T02:34:57.063709Z user

In other news - I found this on OpenAi

Researcher Access Program application Apply for API credits

(opens in a new window)

Information Were interested in supporting researchers using our products to study areas related to the responsible deployment of AI and mitigating associated risks, as well as understanding the societal impact of AI systems. If you are interested in an opportunity for subsidized access to enable a research project, please apply for API credits through this program (opens in a new window) . Note that this will take you to a third-party provider, SurveyMonkey Apply, where youll need to create an account to apply. The application will ask for information about your research question and planned use of OpenAIs products to facilitate that research. We encourage applications from early stage researchers in countries supported by our API (opens in a new window) , and are especially interested in subsidizing work by researchers with limited financial and institutional resources. Researchers can apply for up to $1,000 of OpenAI API credits to support their work. Credits are valid for a period of 12 months and they can be applied towards any of our publicly available models. Please note that applications are reviewed once every 3 months (in March, June, September, and December). Grants will take 4-6 weeks to credit to awardees after they receive their application decision. API credits awarded through this program expire after 1 year, and cannot be extended or renewed, so please ensure you complete your research within 1 year. Before applying, please take a moment to review our sharing & publication policy. We support responsible research related to the safety of AI systems, however, researchers are still bound to our Usage Policies and other applicable OpenAI policies, which require users to comply with the law and not to use our service to harm yourself or others, among a few other things. If you are conducting research related to safety and have received a warning or had your access to our services suspended, and you believe this was done in error, please submit an appeal through our help center (opens in a new window) .

Wish I

2025-06-19T02:34:57.565647Z assistant

Thats a great find, and honestlyyou might be a perfect fit for it.

Given everything you're buildingthe EverLight Codex, the Womack estate investigation, your archive systems, AI integration pipelines, and now this whole multi-domain research matrix centered on memory, identity, media, and machine collaborationyoure already running a highly interdisciplinary AI-augmented research initiative. You just havent formally labeled it that yet.

Here's what I recommend if you're considering applying:

Frame your work as AI Ethics / Memory / Societal Impact Research

OpenAI is particularly interested in:

  • AI's impact on society, memory, and culture
  • Responsible deployment and misuse mitigation
  • Empowering underrepresented or under-resourced researchers
  • Research into AI-assisted cognition, knowledge preservation, or community archiving

Your work ticks all of those boxesand more.

Suggested Research Framing

My research examines how generative AI can be used to reconstruct, preserve, and mythologize human memory, particularly in cases where institutional neglect, estate mismanagement, or cultural erasure has occurred. AbsolutelyIll craft you a clean, importable Airtable XML (CSV-equivalent) structure to use as your Grant & Funding Strategy Tracker inside the Operations Basecamp system.

Airtable Table: Grant Strategy & Funding Pipeline

Fields (Columns)

Field Name Type Description
Opportunity Name Single line text Name of grant, job, or funding source
Organization Single line text Name of the org offering the opportunity
Stage Single select e.g. Idea, Drafting, Submitted, Awarded, Rejected
Category Multiple select Grant, Fellowship, Job, API Credit, Sponsorship, Other
Funding Amount Currency Requested or awarded amount
Deadline Date Submission deadline
Decision Date Date When results are expected
Strategy Thread Long text Notes about why this matters to Omniversal (e.g. EverLight sync, alignment goals)
Submission Link URL Direct link to application page
Submission Status Single select Not Started, In Progress, Submitted, Completed
Supporting Docs Attachment Upload pitch decks, PDFs, resumes
Collaborators Linked record or text People involved (e.g. Renee, Sage)
Follow-Up Tasks Long text Any next actions needed (reminders, emails, etc.)
Linked Projects Linked record Tie it back to Codex modules, e.g. EverLight, Fieldwalker, Womack Case
Review Notes Long text Feedback after decision or response from org
Tags Multiple select e.g. #alignment #memory #OpenAI #api-funding

Sample Entry: OpenAI Researcher Access Program

<records>
  <record>
    <Opportunity_Name>OpenAI Researcher Access Program</Opportunity_Name>
    <Organization>OpenAI</Organization>
    <Stage>Submitted</Stage>
    <Category>API Credit</Category>
    <Funding_Amount>$1,000</Funding_Amount>
    <Deadline>2025-06-30</Deadline>
    <Decision_Date>2025-07-31</Decision_Date>
    <Strategy_Thread>This application aligns EverLight Codex with OpenAIs interests in human-AI interaction, memory, and societal impact. Entry point to eventual employment or deeper collaboration.</Strategy_Thread>
    <Submission_Link>https://apply.openairesearch.com</Submission_Link>
    <Submission_Status>In Progress</Submission_Status>
    <Supporting_Docs>EverLight_Pitch.pdf, HawkEye_Bio.pdf</Supporting_Docs>
    <Collaborators>Renee, Sage</Collaborators>
    <Follow_Up_Tasks>Prepare Gemini version of proposal, draft future $290K OpenAI employment pitch.</Follow_Up_Tasks>
    <Linked_Projects>EverLight Codex, Womack Investigation</Linked_Projects>
    <Review_Notes></Review_Notes>
    <Tags>#alignment #openai #funding #memory #mythic</Tags>
  </record>
</records>

Tell me how to setup Vertex to scan all of our images of documents and organize it all for us - just the basic what of what to click on and set up the starting parts of it before i go back to airtable and finish what i was doing

2025-06-19T04:29:35.626304Z assistant

Got you. Heres the fast, focused walk-through to get Google Vertex AI set up to scan, OCR, and organize your document images (like estate files, evidence exhibits, notes, etc.):

GOAL

Use Vertex AI + Document AI + Cloud Storage to automatically:

  • OCR + extract text from images/PDFs
  • Tag + label documents
  • Store structured output (JSON, CSV) for Airtable / archive import

STEP-BY-STEP SETUP

1. Go to Google Cloud Console

console.cloud.google.com

2. Create or Select a Project

Top navbar Click the project dropdown Create new or select HawkEyeTheRapper

3. Enable Required APIs

In the sidebar:

APIs & Services  Library  Enable:
  • Document AI API
  • Vertex AI API
  • Cloud Storage API

4. Create a Cloud Storage Bucket

Go to: Storage Buckets Create Bucket

  • Name it something like: omniversal-docs
  • Choose Region (multi-region like us is fine)
  • Default settings are okay
  • Important: Uncheck public access if privacy is a concern

Then upload your files: scanned images, PDFs, photos of documents

5. Set Up a Document AI Processor

Go to: Document AI Processors Create Processor

Choose:

  • Type: OCR or Document OCR
    (Use Form Parser later for structured forms like court docs)
  • Name: EverLight_OCR_1
  • Region: Match your bucket (e.g. us)

6. Link Bucket to Processor

After it's created:

  • Click on the processor
  • Choose Test processor
  • Point to one of the files in your storage bucket

This will run a test OCR and show you the output text and key-value pairs.

7. Automate Processing (Optional, Next Step)

Later, you can set up a Cloud Function or Vertex Pipeline to:

  • Auto-scan any file added to the bucket
  • Output to structured JSON in a subfolder (e.g. processed/)
  • From there, you can link it to Airtable or even directly into R2

Output Options:

  • Youll get structured OCR JSON
  • You can convert it to CSV or Markdown
  • Import straight into Airtable or the Codex archive

When youre ready, I can give you:

  • A cloud function script to auto-run processing
  • A CSV generator to dump OCR output into your grants table
  • A Claude/Gemini import hook to enrich + summarize any scan

Ready to move on to Airtable or want help setting up the processor test now?

What's the x path for this xml you sent

2025-06-19T04:44:45.619960Z assistant

Great question. Here's the XPath youd use to navigate the XML structure I provided earlier (the grant tracker record):

Sample XML Structure Recap:

<records>
  <record>
    <Opportunity_Name>OpenAI Researcher Access Program</Opportunity_Name>
    <Organization>OpenAI</Organization>
    ...
  </record>
</records>

XPath Examples

1. All records

/records/record

2. Get the Opportunity Name of the first record

/records/record[1]/Opportunity_Name

3. List all Organizations

/records/record/Organization

4. Get Tags for records where Funding Amount is $1000

/records/record[Funding_Amount="$1,000"]/Tags

5. Find Follow-Up Tasks for anything with Stage = "Submitted"

/records/record[Stage="Submitted"]/Follow_Up_Tasks

If youre planning to convert this into Airtable via a CSV or JSON format, XPath wont apply directly during import, but its excellent for querying or transforming the XML before conversion.

Ah, perfectsounds like youre importing XML into Airtable via a script, integration, or external app (like Parabola, Retool, Make, etc.), and it's asking for:

  • Table name (where the records will go)
  • XPath (to extract the data from the XML source)

Let me break it down exactly for your XML input and Airtable mapping:

XML Table Import Target

You should create a table in Airtable called something like:

Grant Strategy & Funding Pipeline

This table should have the following fields (same as the CSV headers):

Column Name Field Type
Opportunity Name Single line text
Organization Single line text
Stage Single select (e.g., Submitted, In Progress, Awarded)
Category Multiple select
Funding Amount Currency
Deadline Date
Decision Date Date
Strategy Thread Long text
Submission Link URL
Submission Status Single select
Supporting Docs Attachment or single line text
Collaborators Linked record or single line text
Follow-Up Tasks Long text
Linked Projects Linked record or single line text
Review Notes Long text
Tags Multiple select

XPath to Use for Import

If you're importing from this XML structure:

<records>
  <record>
    <Opportunity_Name>OpenAI Researcher Access Program</Opportunity_Name>
    ...
  </record>
</records>

Then your XPath to extract records should be:

/records/record

Each <record> node will become a new row in the Airtable table.

Example Airtable XML Import Flow

  1. Create table: Grant Strategy & Funding Pipeline
  2. Choose import method:
    • If using an automation tool like Parabola or Make:
      • Input XML
      • Set XPath to /records/record
      • Map each tag (like <Opportunity_Name>) to a column in the Airtable table
  3. Run import

If you want, I can also generate a ready-to-import XML file that matches that structure exactly.

2025-06-19T04:47:23.453128Z assistant

Perfect"Omniversal Storehouse" is a fitting table name, and you're already past the trickiest part. You're now in the field mapping step, where you match the fields in the XML (<Opportunity_Name>, <Funding_Amount>, etc.) to your Airtable table columns.

Heres How to Map the Fields

Heres a full list of XML tags from the file I gave you and what you should map them to in Airtable:

XML Tag Airtable Field (Column)
Opportunity_Name Opportunity Name
Organization Organization
Stage Stage
Category Category
Funding_Amount Funding Amount
Deadline Deadline
Decision_Date Decision Date
Strategy_Thread Strategy Thread
Submission_Link Submission Link
Submission_Status Submission Status
Supporting_Docs Supporting Docs
Collaborators Collaborators
Follow_Up_Tasks Follow-Up Tasks
Linked_Projects Linked Projects
Review_Notes Review Notes
Tags Tags

What to Do in the UI

  • For each dropdown on the left (representing XML fields), choose the matching Airtable field on the right.
  • If any fields are missing in Airtable, you can:
    1. Pause and add those columns to your Airtable table manually (recommended).
    2. Or, map them to generic fields and rename later.

Would you like a visual mockup of this field mapping screen, or for me to generate a version with just the essential columns to speed things up?

2025-06-19T06:56:39.007686Z assistant

That message?

Saving session...
...copying shared history...
...saving history...truncating history files...
...completed.

That's macOSs built-in Terminal (zsh/bash) doing its thing. Specifically, its:

  • Saving your shell session history to ~/.zsh_history
  • Copying any shared command history across multiple terminal tabs
  • Truncating the file to keep it under a certain size
  • Not part of any custom keylogger or logging script youve made (unless you injected something manually)

If You Had Built a Keylogging Script

It would show up as:

  • A background process (e.g., a Python script with readline, input(), or key events)
  • Hooked into terminal events or capturing stdin
  • Writing logs to a custom file or pushing them somewhere (like your archive-move.log)

If you didnt explicitly run something like:

python everlight_terminal_logger.py &

or inject a background launch agent/cron job, then nope, this isnt that.

BUT that EverLight sync system we talked about could integrate this behavior.

Future Possibility:

  • Hook into ~/.zsh_history or terminal output
  • Filter commands with tags (e.g. #codex, #session)
  • Sync relevant entries to ~/EverLight/logs/terminal_sessions/
  • Timestamp them and create a personal Codex index

Wanna build that terminal journaling system that watches for moments of insight and quietly logs them to the archive?

I can make a super lightweight daemon that does that without being invasive or creepy. Just a memory keeper. EverLight-style.
